  physical_appearance: This is a Ming dynasty Kraak ware.  Painted on its exterior are eight panels of deer amidst flowering shrubs. The deers alternate between spotted and non-spotted ones. Similar to its exterior
 its interior\u0027s central medallion shows the side profile of a spotted deer amongst vertical shrubs. Its interior rim however
 comprises of panels that enclose single potted peaches and flowers.

  context_1: The dish was exhibited in the Exhibition of Chinese Blue-and-White Ceramics exhibition held at the National Museum of Singapore in April 1978. It is featured as number 156 in the exhibition catalogue.

  sgcool_label_text: This bowl is painted on the exterior with eight panels of deer amid flowering shrubs
 while the interior features a deer at the centre as well as panels decorated with peaches and flowers. The deer and peach were frequently used to decorate Chinese porcelain as they were associated with immortality. The panelled ornamentation and thin walls of the porcelain bowl are characteristic features of Kraak porcelain
 a major type of Chinese export ware during the late Ming dynasty.  \r\n\r\nThe term ‘Kraak’ was probably derived from the word ‘carrack’ referring to a type of Portuguese trading vessel. It might have also come from the Dutch word kraken which means ‘to break’ or the name for a style of shelves used for porcelain display in Dutch homes.\r\n

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a Ming dynasty Kraak ware.  Painted on its exterior are eight panels of deer amidst flowering shrubs. The deers alternate between spotted and non-spotted ones. Similar to its exterior, its interior's central medallion shows the side profile of a spotted deer amongst vertical shrubs. Its interior rim however, comprises of panels that enclose single potted peaches and flowers.

metadata.sgcool_label_text:
This bowl is painted on the exterior with eight panels of deer amid flowering shrubs, while the interior features a deer at the centre as well as panels decorated with peaches and flowers. The deer and peach were frequently used to decorate Chinese porcelain as they were associated with immortality. The panelled ornamentation and thin walls of the porcelain bowl are characteristic features of Kraak porcelain, a major type of Chinese export ware during the late Ming dynasty.  

The term ‘Kraak’ was probably derived from the word ‘carrack’ referring to a type of Portuguese trading vessel. It might have also come from the Dutch word kraken which means ‘to break’ or the name for a style of shelves used for porcelain display in Dutch homes.
